libgcc_s.so.1 exists in /usr/local/lib which is in the path. is there mayb a 
startup-option to explicitely specify library-pathes?
Potential dup of bug 43811?

If libgcc_s.so.1 is in /usr/local/lib, try exporting LD_LIBRARY_PATH to be
/usr/local/lib before running eclipse.
does not help.

Run ldd on the file /usr/local/lib/libgcc_s.so.1 and check to see if it has all
of its dependencies.

ldd /usr/local/lib/libgcc_s.so.1
warning: ldd: /usr/local/lib/libgcc_s.so.1: is not executable
        libc.so.1 =>     /usr/lib/libc.so.1
        libdl.so.1 =>    /usr/lib/libdl.so.1
        /usr/platform/SUNW,Sun-Fire-880/lib/libc_psr.so.1

I would recommend making it executable and see if that helps.  This seems pretty
strange, though.

nope.
copied libgcc_s.so.1 to the eclipse folder (am no admin -- can't chmod in /usr), chmod'ed and set 
LD_LIBRARY_PATH to .
same problem as before. i'm not really able to figure out _who_ misses this lib.

On Solaris for 3.1 M5a you must extract the eclipse download using gnu tar.  
If you extract using the default tar, it will result in a message about a 
checksum error and if you continue and launch eclipse anyway then random 
errors will happen.  Are you sure you extracted the files using GNU tar 
(http://www.gnu.org/software/tar/tar.html) to extract these files?

See also https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=82568

i transfered the whole archive to a suse linux machine and extracted using gnu tar and gzip - so the files 
should be ok - and copied back to the solaris station via nfs.
'cause i'm no admin i can't install software with no further ado - is there a gnu tar binary running without 
install (i don't know about solaris-software)?
regarding this issue i filed 88025 and suggested to provide zip-archives too

>i transfered the whole archive to a suse linux machine and extracted using 
>gnu tar and gzip - so the files should be ok - and copied back to the 
>solaris station via nfs.

When you used gnu tar, did this fix the problem or do you still have the 
problem?  Rather than copying via nfs, you could zip up the result and copy 
the zip file.  We have requested that the Solaris/AIX/HPUX downloads be 
provided in zip format in the future.

nope. 
moving to linux, 
unpacking with gnu-tar, 
repacking with zip ("This is Zip 2.3 (November 29th 1999), by Info-ZIP."), 
moving new archive to solaris again and 
... finally unpacking with zip ("This is Zip 2.2 (November 3rd 1997), by Info-ZIP.") 
does not help.

Found this post which might help:

http://ruptured-duck.com/jed-users-2002/msg00362.html

What version of libgcc_s do you have installed?

nope. the libgcc seems of gcc2.95. 
seems i need gcc3.x? i'm no solaris admin so i can't install any software globally -- is there a way to 
install gcc+libs as user?
does eclipse 3.1 m5a compile with gcc2.95? (i'm pretty sure they're killing me ... but anyway ;-)

I believe you can install gcc+libs as the user to some place that you have 
write access by using the "--prefix" option.  e.g.

configure --prefix=/home/myaccount/gcc3.X/

Then you just need to include the library on your LD_LIBRARY_PATH.

We are compiling against GCC_3.3.  We can investigate if it is possible to 
compile against an earlier version.

i don't want to compile libgcc (am not even sure whether the necessary files are in place). don't know 
how to install solaris sw (from sunfreeware.com) as user.
but could you somehow validate whether the libgcc-version really is an issue (i'm pretty sure it is ...)?

requested successfully the iunstallation of libgcc3.4 ... but the error persist :-(
maybe the path to libgcc_s.so.1 is hardwired somewhere?

Billy, can you try and recreate the problem and help Arne debug his 
installation?

Arne, have you tried running the application gtk-demo that comes with GTK?  It 
is located in the bin of the GTK installation (e.g. /usr/local/gtk-
2.4.14/bin/gtk-demo).  If it fails to run, then there may be problems with the 
GTK installation that we need to work through.

are there dependencies on an already installed gtk 2.4?? i presumed eclipse to have all (at 
least gui-related) needed stuff included.
it's a pretty old solaris8 installation with a likewise pretty old gnome 2.0 included. a 
release for solaris 8 should be aware of that.

#82206 describes the problem and a possible solution.
btw: even eclipse 3.0.2 has this issue.

Solaris 8 does not ship with GNOME, although it seems you can download a version
from the Sun website.  Is this the version of GNOME you are using?  I believe we
require at least GTK+ 2.2.1.

I'm just going to mark this as a duplicate, please reply on the dup'ed bug.

*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 82206 ***
